items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message:
This flood alert remains in force due to this week’s high spring tides. The forecast high water is 19:30 on 30/09/23 with a level of 6.93 mAOD and a Force 4 southerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high-water time at Hinkley. mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail, please refer to local tide tables.

Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at this time and conditions may apply for a period either side of the high tide. Flooding is possible for the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir.

This current spring-tide sequence peaks this evening, 30/09/2023. Tides in coming days remain high but will be dropping. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads, and stay aware in case further warnings are issued. We are monitoring the situation closely, and this message will be updated by midday on Sunday 01/10/2023 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The next high tide at Richmond at 17:00 on 01/10/23, may result in brief low-level flooding of riverside roads and open spaces.

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 20 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next 3 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 01/10/23, or as the situation changes, as subsequent tides over the next couple of days may be higher.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River and lake levels are expected to remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water due to recent rainfall.
Areas most at risk include The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.
Lake levels remain high at the Lodore gauge.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 01/10/2023.

items.description: Keswick Campsite
items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.
Further rainfall is expected tonight and we will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths.

items.description: River Alt, Formby to Huyton
items.message:
River levels are continue to rise on the River Alt following rain overnight 30/09/2023 into Sunday morning 1/10/2023.
Areas most at risk include River Alt and other watercourses from Huyton to Hightown including, Kirkby, Fazakerley, Maghull, Formby, Aughton, Sefton and Lunt.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 3:00pm on 01/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Sunday's tides at 01:00 and 13:30 on 01/10/2023 and Monday's early morning tide at 01:45 on 02/10/2023 will all be very similar. Approximately 6.14 metres Chart Datum (3.09 mAOD) at Littlehampton. The wind and pressure is not expected to increase tide tables significantly. For 2 hours either side of each high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. The tide levels are a little higher than normal over the next three days. Monday's afternoon tide is predicted to be 15cm higher than Sunday's. This may cause some impacts at each high water until Tuesday‚ but where impacts do occur‚ they will be very minor. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 17:00 on 01/10/2023.

items.description: Christchurch Harbour
North Cornwall coast from Lands End to Chapel Porth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Saturday evening. 

High water at St Ives is at 6.43pm, flooding is possible one hour either side of high tide. Times of high water will vary along the coast.

Very high spring tides, accompanied by force 6 southerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 2m, could cause overtopping of quays and flooding to low-lying roads, car parks and footpaths.

The communities most at risk include Sennen, St Ives, Carbis Bay, Lelant, Portreath and Porthtowan.

People are advised to take care near the coast. Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. 

We will continue to monitor the situation and will update this information by midday on Sunday.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Newlyn is 3.13 mAOD, this is 0.09 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: High spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning (02/10/2023). Flooding is possible at The North Sea coast from Mappleton to Spurn Point on Monday 02/10/2023 from 6:30AM to 9:15AM. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9pm on 01/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message: The forecast weather conditions during spring tides, means that high tides are expected  between 7:45am and 9:45am tomorrow morning, Monday 2 October.  Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront.  Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of  5.06mAODN at 8:45am, on Monday 2 October, which is 0.35m above tide tables, wind Force 2, South Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The following tide on Monday at 9:30pm is currently forecast to be below the Alert threshold. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Monday 2 October

items.description: Coast from Heacham to north of King's Lynn in Norfolk
items.message: The forecast weather conditions during spring tides, means that high tides are expected  between 7:45am and 9:45am tomorrow morning, Monday 2 October.  Areas most at risk are Heacham, Snettisham, Ingoldisthorpe, Dersingham and Wolferton. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of  5.06mAODN at 8:45am, on Monday 2 October, which is 0.35m above tide tables, wind Force 2, South Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The following tide on Monday at 9:30pm is currently forecast to be below the Alert threshold. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Monday 2 October

items.description: Northumberland coast
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast early Sunday morning on 01/10/2023.

Flooding to low lying land, beaches, roads and footpaths is possible between 04:00 AM and 06:00 AM.

Areas of particular risk include Alnmouth river footpath and Alnmouth horse field.

Tide levels are expected to be higher than usual due to the high spring tides. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Please stay away from low lying land, roads, riverside footpaths and coastal footpaths as high water levels, large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

This message will be updated by 17:00PM 01/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: West Bay Harbour
items.message:
As a result of high spring tides, levels will be at their highest this evening at 08:00 PM on 1/10/2023. The forecast high water level is 2.47m.
Areas most at risk include West Bay Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Brit.
Flooding is possible at West Bay Harbour and the tidal stretch of the River Brit between 06:45 PM and 10:00 PM on 1/10/2023.
The next high tide is expected to be higher than normal and may result in us issuing a further alert.
We are closely monitoring the situation remotely during the high water with duty staff on standby to react as required. 
Consider activating any property flood protection products.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 2/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Ramsgate to Kingsdown
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. The risk of flooding along the coast from Ramsgate to Kingsdown has now reduced.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. We continue to monitor the situation.  
Tides are forecast to remain high over the weekend and early next week, after which they are expected to reduce. Please stay aware in case further alerts are issued.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
This flood alert remains in place as a result of high spring tides until tomorrow evening 02/10/2023.

Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.

Forecast high water at 21:30 this evening is at a level of 7.86 mAOD with a Force 3 westerly wind. Times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth, however conditions may apply up to one hour either side of the high tide. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible but properties are not expected to flood. We have closed flood gates at Pill and Shirehampton and are monitoring the situation.

This flood alert will be updated on Monday 02/10/23.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message: As a result of high spring tides, flooding of roads and farmland is possible on the high tides at 8:45pm today, 30/09/23 and 9:15am tomorrow, 30/09/23. A series of high tides is due over the weekend peaking on Saturday evening, 01/10/23. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 8.0 to 8.3m at 9:00pm this evening, 30/09/23 and 7.6 to 7.9m at 9:15am tomorrow morning, 01/10/23. Newport 7.7 to 7.9m at 8:45pm this evening, 29/09/23 and 7.2 to 7.5m at 9:15am tomorrow morning, 01/10/23. This mornings tidal peaks, Saturday, 30/09/23 were:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.67m and Newport 7.35m. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 2pm on Sunday 01/10/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides on the afternoon of Sunday 1st October. 

Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads at Fiddlers Ferry between 13:45 and 14:15, Eastford Road between 14:00 and 14:30 and Arpley Bridge between 14:15 and 14:45. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. 

The next high tide is expected to be higher than normal and may result in us issuing a further alert. 

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. 

Please be careful along footpaths and roads next to the river as they could be dangerous. 

This message will be updated by 16:00 on 01-10-2023

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force for the high tide forecast at 1:30am on Monday 02/10/2023.  The high tide at lunchtime on Sunday 01/10/2023 at 1:00pm is not expected to reach threshold.  Areas most at risk include Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stanah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods. With high spring tides, this situation is likely to be repeated for every high tide from now until Monday 02/10/2023. We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 3:00pm on 01/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the next 5 high tides, until after the hide tide of Sunday evening 1st of October. High water at Ilfracombe is at 18:56 Friday 29th September, 0718 and 19:38 on Saturday 30th September and 07:57 and 20:18 on Sunday 1st October, times of high water will vary along the coast. The tides will be peak for high tide of Saturday evening.
Strong force 6, southerly winds are forecast to cause sea spray in exposed coastal locations.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide levels at Ilfracombe are over 5 metres across the next 5 high tides with a peak of 5.32m for the evening high tide of Saturday 30th September mAOD.

items.description: Coast from Silloth to St Bees
items.message:
The Flood Alert has now been removed. 
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide of Saturday evening. High water at Plymouth is at 7.24pm, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Force 4 southerly winds are forecast.  Low-lying areas and communities in the Erme, Avon, Kingsbridge, Dart, Teign and Exe Estuaries may be affected.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Plymouth is 2.86 mAOD, this is 0.05 metres above astronomical tide level.

items.description: Somerset coast at Clevedon
items.message:
This flood alert has been issued due to high spring-tide water levels. The forecast high water is at 20:00 on 30/09/23 with a level of 7.89 mAOD and a Force 4 southerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high-water time at Avonmouth. mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail, please refer to local tide tables. 

Flooding is possible for the coastline between Gullhouse Point and Marine Parade. Flooding to roads and low-lying land is possible at this time, however conditions may apply for a period either side of the high tide. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.

The evening high tide on 30/09/2023 is the peak of the current spring tide sequence. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads, and stay aware in case further warnings are issued. We are monitoring the situation closely, and this message will be updated by midday on Sunday 01/10/2023 or as the situation changes.

All times are local and refer to the high-water time at Hinkley. mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail, please refer to local tide tables. 

Flooding to low-lying areas and farmland is possible at this time, and conditions may apply for a period either side of the high tide. Flooding is possible for coastal and tidal areas at Minehead, Combwich, Bridgwater, Burnham-on-Sea, Uphill, Weston-super-Mare, Kewstoke, Sand Bay and Kingston Seymour. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this time.

The evening high tide on 30/09/2023 is the peak of the current spring tide sequence. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads, and stay aware in case further warnings are issued. We are monitoring the situation closely, and this message will be updated by midday on Sunday 01/10/2023 or as the situation changes.

items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.
The next high spring tide will be this afternoon at 01:15 PM on Sunday 01/10/2023.
Areas most at risk include Sandside.
No property flooding is expected.
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next two days and as a result we will issue further alerts.
We have closed flood gates in the area.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 01/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tyne estuary

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.message:
This Flood Alert remains in place due to the high tides forecast from early Sunday morning on 01/10/2023.

Flooding to low lying land, roads and footpaths is possible between 04:00 AM and 06:00 AM on Sunday 01/10/2023. Areas most at risk include from Wylam to the North Sea coast, including Watergate Car Park at Newcastle Quayside.

Tide levels are expected to be higher than usual due to the high spring tides. The early morning tide for Monday is also forecast to be higher than usual, and therefore we expect this alert to remain in force over the weekend. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Please stay away from riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads as high water levels, large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

This message will be updated by 17:00PM on 01/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed as the risk of flooding has now reduced. Forecast tide levels are falling and coastal conditions should ease from tonight’s tide 01/10/2023.
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: Somerset coast at Portishead and Portbury Dock
items.message:
This flood alert has been issued due to high spring-tide water levels. The forecast high water is at 20:00 on 30/09/23 with a level of 7.89 mAOD and a Force 4 southerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high-water time at Avonmouth. mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail, please refer to local tide tables. 

Flooding is possible for the coastline between Portishead Point and Avonmouth. Flooding to roads and low-lying land is possible at this time, however conditions may apply for a period either side of the high tide.

The evening high tide on 30/09/2023 is the peak of the current spring tide sequence. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads, and stay aware in case further warnings are issued. We are monitoring the situation closely, and this message will be updated by midday on Sunday 01/10/2023 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Portishead and Portbury Dock, seafront properties and Portbury Dock areas
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.

We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: Wye Estuary at Brockweir
items.message:
A series of high tides has been building over the last few days and have peaked this evening 30/09/23.  Peak levels this evening 30/09/23 were Newport 7.79m at 8:45 pm and Avonmouth 8.15m at 9pm.
Flooding to properties, roads and farmland is expected around 9:15am on Sunday morning during the next high tide, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. High tides may affect properties and roads including outhouses and garages in Brockweir. Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.7m to 8.0m at 9:15 am,  Newport 7.3m to 7.5m at 9:15 am 01/10/23   

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are on patrol during the period of high tide.  
  
This message will be updated by 2pm Sunday 01/10/23.

items.description: Tidal Trent for riverside areas from Gainsborough to the Humber confluence

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Lincolnshire, North Lincolnshire, Nottinghamshire

items.message: River levels are forecast to rise at the Keadby river gauge as a result of high spring tides and strong winds causing a tidal surge. Flooding is expected on high tides at 08:45 AM on 01/10/2023 and 09:15 AM on 02/10/2023 at Keadby. Areas most at risk are Keadby, Amcotts, Owston, Burringham, Gunness, Althorpe, East Butterwick, Flixborough, Gunness Lane and, Neap House road. We expect river levels to peak on the high tide at 09:00 AM on 01/10/2023 and 09:45 AM on 02/10/2023 at Keadby. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 01/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn Vyrnwy confluence
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 05:00 today, 01/10/2023.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. Predicted peaks:-  Llanymynech 3.7 to 4.0m on Sunday afternoon, 01/10/2023; Cae Howel 2.0 to 2.5m Sunday evening, 01/10/2023.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 17:00 on 01/10/2023 or if the situation changes.

items.description: King's Lynn, West Lynn and The Wash frontage in Norfolk
items.message: The forecast weather conditions during spring tides, means that high tides are expected  between 7:45am and 9:45am tomorrow morning, Monday 2 October.  Areas most at risk are King's Lynn, West Lynn, Clenchwarton, Terrington St Clement, Walpole Cross Keys and Tilney All Saints. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of  5.06mAODN at 8:45am, on Monday 2 October, which is 0.35m above tide tables, wind Force 2, South Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The following tide on Monday at 9:30pm is currently forecast to be below the Alert threshold. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Monday 2 October

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels are forecast to rise at the Gainsborough river gauge as a result of high spring tides and strong winds causing a tidal surge. Flooding is possible with peak high tides at 10:15 AM and 10:45 PM at Gainsborough on 01/10/2023 and 10:45 AM at Gainsborough on 02/10/2023. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road and Lea Marsh, Gainsborough, Morton, East and West Stockwith, Trent Wharfage and Gainsborough Railway Bridge. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 01/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent at Alkborough Flats
items.message: River levels are rising at the Keadby river gauge as a result of high spring tides and strong winds causing a tidal surge. Flooding is expected on high tides at 08:45 AM on 01/10/2023 and 09:15 AM on 02/10/2023 at Keadby. The area most at risk is the Alkborough Flats. The Keadby river gauge is forecast to overtop the lower spillway and result in flooding. We expect river levels to peak on the high tide at 09:00 AM on 01/10/2023 and 09:45 AM on 02/10/2023 at Keadby. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 3:00 PM on 01/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Heysham to Cockerham
items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force for the high tide forecast at 1:30am on Monday 02/10/2023.  The high tide at lunchtime on Sunday 01/10/2023 at 1:00pm is not expected to reach threshold .  Areas most at risk include Sandylands, Middleton, Sunderland, Bank Houses, Hillam, Sand Side and Cockerham Moss. With high spring tides, this situation is likely to be repeated for every high tide from now until Monday 02/10/2023. We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 3:00pm on 01/10/2023, or as the situation changes.

There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely and issue any further warnings or alerts as necessary.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
As a result of high spring tides peaking tonight, Saturday 30/09/23. Flooding to roads and farmland is expected, however conditions may apply a few hours either side of the high tide. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. Locations that may be affected include areas river side of defences, including Lydney Harbour. Low lying land at Purton on the east bank may also be impacted. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. Predicted peaks:- Sharpness 10.3m to 10.6m tonight at 9:45pm, 30/09/23 and 9.8m to 10.1m at 10am tomorrow morning, 01/10/23. Flooding is not forecast at other gauge locations. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 2pm on Sunday, 01/10/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wye Estuary at Elmdale, Chepstow

The predicted peaks for Sunday morning are lower Newport 7.3 - 7.5m at 9:15 am and Avonmouth 7.7 - 8m at 9:15 am.
A flood alert remains in force for the wider area so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
